column1: The Alemanni cross the frozen Rhine in large numbers invading the Roman Empire.
Roman consuls begin their year in office.
Pope Leo X excommunicates Martin Luther in the papal bull Decet Romanum Pontificem.
Julius Caesar defeats Titus Labienus in the Battle of Ruspina.
Edward the Confessor dies childless sparking a succession crisis that will eventually lead to the Norman conquest of England.
Harold Godwinson (or Harold II) is crowned King of England.
Jin Huidi Chinese Emperor of the Jin dynasty is poisoned and succeeded by his son Jin Huaidi.
Byzantine Emperor Zeno is forced to flee his capital at Constantinople and his general Basiliscus gains control of the empire.
Julius Caesar crosses the Rubicon signaling the start of civil war.
Nika riots in Constantinople: A quarrel between supporters of different chariot teams—the Blues and the Greens—in the Hippodrome escalates into violence.
Gustav I of Sweden is crowned king.
Nika riots in Constantinople.
Mercurius becomes Pope John II the first pope to adopt a new name upon elevation to the papacy.
The Julian calendar takes effect as the civil calendar of the Roman Empire establishing January 1 as the new date of the new year.
By the Coonan Cross Oath the Eastern Church in India cuts itself off from colonial Portuguese tutelage.
Battle of Reading: Æthelred of Wessex fights and is defeated by a Danish invasion army.
Battle of Nancy: Charles the Bold is killed and Burgundy becomes part of France.
Reconquista: Alfonso the Battler conquers Zaragoza.
Siyaj K'ak' conquers Waka
Twelfth Council of Toledo: King Erwig of the Visigoths initiates a council in which he implements diverse measures against the Jews in Spain.
The Western Han dynasty ends when Wang Mang claims that the divine Mandate of Heaven called for the end of the dynasty and the beginning of his own the Xin dynasty.
Theodora is crowned Empress of the Byzantine Empire.
Bayinnaung who would go on to assemble the largest empire in the history of Southeast Asia is crowned King of Burma.
Odo Count of Paris becomes King of the Franks.
Reconquista: the Emirate of Granada the last Moorish stronghold in Spain surrenders.
The Roman Senate posthumously deifies Julius Caesar
Benning Wentworth issues the first of the New Hampshire Grants leading to the establishment of Vermont.
Anne of Brittany announces that all those who would ally with the King of France will be considered guilty of the crime of lèse-majesté.
Duke Ludovico Sforza conquers Milan.
Philip of Swabia becomes King of the Romans.
Alfred the Great leads a West Saxon army to repel an invasion by Danelaw Vikings.
Jin
column2: Song Wars: Invading Jurchen soldiers from the Jin dynasty besiege and sack Bianjing (Kaifeng) the capital of the Song dynasty of China and abduct Emperor Qinzong and others ending the Northern Song dynasty.

column1: Lucius Calpurnius Piso Licinianus is appointed by Galba as deputy Roman Emperor.
Vladislav II becomes King of Bohemia.
The city of Belém is founded in Pará Brazil by Francisco Caldeira Castelo Branco.
Sicut Dudum forbidding the enslavement of the Guanche natives in Canary Islands by the Spanish is promulgated by Pope Eugene IV.
American Revolutionary War: American forces under the command of George Washington repulsed a British attack at the Battle of the Assunpink Creek near Trenton New Jersey.
The Roman legions in Germania Superior refuse to swear loyalty to Galba. They rebel and proclaim Vitellius as emperor.
The first issue of Berlingske Denmark's oldest continually operating newspaper is published.
King Charles I of England sends soldiers to arrest members of Parliament commencing England's slide into civil war.
Felix Manz a leader of the Anabaptist congregation in Zurich Switzerland is executed by drowning.
Stephen Uroš III is crowned King of Serbia.
François Grimaldi disguised as a monk leads his men to capture the fortress protecting the Rock of Monaco establishing his family as the rulers of Monaco.
Prince Hailing of Jin and other court officials murder Emperor Xizong of Jin. Hailing succeeds him as emperor.
Pope Fabian succeeds Anterus to become the twentieth pope of Rome.
First recorded lottery in England.
Mission Santa Clara de Asís is founded in what is now Santa Clara California.
Henry Howard Earl of Surrey is sentenced to death.
Georgia becomes the fourth state to ratify the United States Constitution.
The Senate chooses Pertinax against his will to succeed Commodus as Roman emperor.
American General George Washington defeats British General Lord Cornwallis at the Battle of Princeton.
English Civil War: The Rump Parliament votes to put Charles I on trial.
A great fire occurs in Eindhoven Netherlands.
Charles I of Bohemia is crowned with the Iron Crown of Lombardy as King of Italy in Milan.
The papal bull Romanus Pontifex is written.
The Jewish population of Basel Switzerland believed by the residents to be the cause of the ongoing Black Death is rounded up and incinerated.
Robert Guiscard conquers Palermo.
Austrian nobility is granted freedom of religion.
The organizational meeting that led to the creation of the Wernerian Natural History Society a former Scottish learned society is held in Edinburgh Scotland.
The Bank of Genoa fails after announcement of national bankruptcy in Spain.
Big Bottom massacre in the Ohio Country marking the beginning of the Northwest Indian War.
An infuriated Roman mob tears Telemachus a Christian monk to pieces for trying to stop a gladiators' fight in the public arena held in Rome.
Austria the United Kingdom and France form a secret defensive alliance against Prussia and Russia.
The Netherlands Great Britain and France sign the Triple Alliance.
Battle of Colmar: the French army beats Brandenburg.
Constantine XI is crowned Byzantine Emperor at Mystras.
Louis XII of France marries Anne of Brittany.
Judges' investigations for the trial of Joan of Arc begin in Rouen France the seat of the English occupation government.
Stephen III of Moldavia defeats the Ottoman Empire at the Battle of Vaslui.
A powerful earthquake destroys parts of Sicily and Malta.

John Rennie's scheme to defend St Mary's Church Reculver founded in 669 from coastal erosion was abandoned in favour of demolition despite the church being an exemplar of Anglo-Saxon architecture and sculpture.
French traveller Jean-Baptiste Tavernier arrived in Dhaka and met Shaista Khan.
The British Institution of Civil Engineers is founded.
Galla Placidia half-sister of Emperor Honorius is married to the Visigothic king Ataulf at Narbonne. The wedding is celebrated with Roman festivities and magnificent gifts from the Gothic booty.
Stephen F. Austin receives a grant of land in Texas from the government of Mexico.
Great Britain declares war on Spain and Naples.

Louis XV of France survives an assassination attempt by Robert-François Damiens the last person to be executed in France by drawing and quartering the traditional and gruesome form of capital punishment used for regicides.
The Catholic Monarchs Ferdinand and Isabella enter Granada completing the Reconquista.
Last execution for blasphemy in Britain; of Thomas Aikenhead student at Edinburgh.
Afghans defeat Marathas in the Battle of Barari Ghat.
Archbishop William Laud is beheaded at the Tower of London.
In Philadelphia Pennsylvania the first American life insurance company is incorporated.
The Palermo rising takes place in Sicily against the Bourbon Kingdom of the Two Sicilies.
Nicolas Jean Hugon de Bassville representative of Revolutionary France lynched by a mob in Rome
Reassertion of British sovereignty over the Falkland Islands.
Emperor Honorius forces Galla Placidia into marriage to Constantius his famous general (magister militum).
Joseph Jenkins Roberts is sworn in as the first president of the independent African Liberia.
Constantine Hangerli arrives in Bucharest Wallachia as its new Prince invested by the Ottoman Empire.
American Revolutionary War: Richmond Virginia is burned by British naval forces led by Benedict Arnold.
King Henry VIII of England marries Anne of Cleves.
Premiere performance of George Frideric Handel's Ariodante at the Royal Opera House Covent Garden.
Connecticut becomes the fifth state to be admitted to the United States.
Thomas Paine publishes his pamphlet Common Sense.
Ching-Thang Khomba is crowned King of Manipur.
The Royal Aeronautical Society is formed in London.

French Revolutionary Wars: A naval battle between a French ship of the line and two British frigates off the coast of Brittany ends with the French vessel running aground resulting in over 900 deaths.
The discovery of the planet Vulcan is announced at a meeting of the French Academy of Sciences in Paris France.
Grand Prince Stephen I of Hungary is named the first King of Hungary by Pope Sylvester II.
American Civil War: Delaware votes not to secede from the United States.
Samuel Colt sells his first revolver pistol to the United States government.
The United States House of Representatives votes to stop sharing the Oregon Territory with the United Kingdom.
The Union of Arras is signed.
Second Jacobite rising: Bonnie Prince Charlie occupies Stirling.
Jean-Pierre Blanchard becomes the first person to fly in a balloon in the United States.
The Siege of Dunlap's Station begins near Cincinnati during the Northwest Indian War.
American Revolutionary War: French troops begin a siege of a British garrison on Brimstone Hill in Saint Kitts.
Yohannes IV is crowned Emperor of Ethiopia in Axum the first imperial coronation in that city in over 200 years.
War of 1812: British troops capture Fort Peter in St. Marys Georgia the only battle of the war to take place in the state.
Uruguayan War: The Siege of Paysandú ends as Brazilian and Coloradans capture Paysandú Uruguay.
Romanos IV Diogenes marries Eudokia Makrembolitissa and is crowned Byzantine Emperor.
Meiji Restoration in Japan: The Tokugawa shogunate is abolished; agents of Satsuma and Chōshū seize power.
The McDonald Islands are discovered by Captain William McDonald aboard the Samarang.
Dreyfus affair: French army officer Alfred Dreyfus is stripped of his rank and sentenced to life imprisonment on Devil's Island.
English Restoration: The Fifth Monarchists unsuccessfully attempt to seize control of London England.
George Washington delivers the first State of the Union address in New York New York.
British Prime Minister William Pitt the Younger introduces an income tax of two shillings to the pound to raise funds for Great Britain's war effort in the Napoleonic Wars.
Dutch settlers in Cape Town surrender to the British.
William Herschel discovers Titania and Oberon two moons of Uranus.
The National Trust is founded in the United Kingdom.
The design of the Greek flag is adopted by the First National Assembly at Epidaurus.
Amadeus I becomes King of Spain.
Michael VIII Palaiologos is proclaimed co-emperor of the Empire of Nicaea with his ward John IV Laskaris.
Construction of the Brooklyn Bridge begins.
The New Apostolic Church a Christian and chiliastic church is established in Hamburg Germany.
An Austrian newspaper reports that Wilhelm Röntgen has discovered a type of radiation later known as X-rays.
Joseph son of Emperor Leopold I becomes King of the Romans.
Cape Colony becomes a British colony.
Admiral Horatio Lord Nelson receives a state funeral and is interred in St Paul's Cathedral.
Napoleon Bonaparte divorces his first wife Joséphine.
The Michigan Territory is created.
Itō Hirobumi begins his third term as Prime Minister of Japan.
The Great Fire of New Orleans begins.
American statesman and diplomat John Hay announces the Open Door Policy to promote trade with China.
Albert II of Habsburg is crowned King of Hungary.
Sino-French War: Beginning of the Battle of Núi Bop
The New York Stock Exchange opens its first permanent headquarters at 10-12 Broad near Wall Street in New York City.
Irish leader John Redmond calls for a revolt against British rule.
The Committee of Inquiry on the South Sea Bubble publishes its findings.
An unsuccessful slave revolt is led by Charles Deslondes in St. Charles and St. James Louisiana.
Sir Humphry Davy tests his safety lamp for miners at Hebburn Colliery.
American Civil War: Florida secedes from the Union.
Alabama secedes from the United States.
Thirteen crew members and five apprentices are rescued from the stricken schooner Forest Hall by the Lynmouth Lifeboat when the former founders off the coast of Devon.
United States President Andrew Jackson writes to Vice President Martin Van Buren expressing his opposition to South Carolina's defiance of federal authority in the Nullification Crisis.
Russo-Japanese War: The Russian garrison surrenders at Port Arthur China.
The present-day location of Rio de Janeiro Brazil is first explored by the Portuguese.
The refracting telescope at the Lick Observatory measuring 91 cm in diameter is used for the first time. It was the largest telescope in the world at the time.
Sofia is emancipated from Ottoman rule.
Kappa Alpha Psi the world's second oldest and largest black fraternity is founded at Indiana University.
In the Battle of Jersey the British defeat the last attempt by France to invade Jersey.
War of 1812: Battle of New Orleans
column2: Andrew Jackson leads American forces in victory over the British.

column1: The Portuguese prince Pedro I of Brazil decides to stay in Brazil against the orders of the Portuguese King João VI beginning the Brazilian independence process.
The London Underground the world's oldest underground railway opens between London Paddington station and Farringdon station.
American Civil War: Battle of Arkansas Post
column2: General John McClernand and Admiral David Dixon Porter capture the Arkansas River for the Union.

column1: Uddevalla Suffrage Association is formally dissolved.
The steamship Lexington burns and sinks four miles off the coast of Long Island with the loss of 139 lives.
A gun battle in the East End of London left two dead and sparked a political row over the involvement of then-Home Secretary Winston Churchill.
King Francis I of France succeeds to the French throne.
A magnitude 7.7 earthquake destroys the city of Almaty in Russian Turkestan.
The Fabian Society is founded in London England United Kingdom.
The Prague Party Conference takes place.
Combined British Portuguese and colonial Brazilian forces begin the Invasion of Cayenne during the Napoleonic Wars.
The United States national debt is zero for the only time.
The French Academy of Sciences announces the Daguerreotype photography process.
John D. Rockefeller incorporates Standard Oil.
American Civil War: CSS Alabama encounters and sinks the USS Hatteras off Galveston Lighthouse in Texas.

Sir Henry Campbell-Bannerman's cabinet (which included amongst its members H. H. Asquith David Lloyd George and Winston Churchill) embarks on sweeping social reforms after a Liberal landslide in the British general election.

Dr. William Brydon an assistant surgeon in the British East India Company Army during the First Anglo-Afghan War becomes famous for being the sole survivor of an army of 4500 men and 12000 camp followers when he reaches the safety of a garrison in Jalalabad Afghanistan.
The second Palmer Raid takes place with another 6000 suspected communists and anarchists arrested and held without trial. These raids take place in several U.S. cities.
Croatian nobles elect Ferdinand I of Austria as King of Croatia in the Parliament on Cetin.

At the Paris Peace Conference Emir Faisal I of Iraq signs an agreement with Zionist leader Chaim Weizmann on the development of a Jewish homeland in Palestine and an Arab nation in a large part of the Middle East.
The Oklahoma Land Run opens 2 million acres of unused Oklahoma Territory to first serve first come settlers on April 22.

First Balkan War: During the Battle of Lemnos Greek admiral Pavlos Kountouriotis forces the Turkish fleet to retreat to its base within the Dardanelles from which it did not venture for the rest of the war.
Alfred Vail demonstrates a telegraph system using dots and dashes (this is the forerunner of Morse code).
American Civil War: Second Battle of Springfield
The Fort Tejon earthquake strikes California registering an estimated magnitude of 7.9.
The first great Texas oil gusher is discovered at Spindletop in Beaumont Texas.
The Anglo-Zulu War begins.
A long-distance radio message is sent from the Eiffel Tower for the first time.
The Treaty of Cahuenga ends the Mexican
Angered by the anti-clerical provisions of the Mexican Constitution of 1917 Catholic rebels in Mexico rebelled against the government.
Scotland begins its numbered year on January 1 instead of March 25.
Benito Mussolini announces he is taking dictatorial powers over Italy.
Utah is admitted as the 45th U.S. state.
The Ford Motor Company announces an eight-hour workday and that it would pay a "living wage" of at least $5 for a day's labor.
The most damaging storm in 300 years sweeps across Ireland damaging or destroying more than 20% of the houses in Dublin.
African American men are granted the right to vote in Washington D.C.
Anson Jones the last President of the Republic of Texas commits suicide.
World War I: In the Erzurum Offensive Russia defeats the Ottoman Empire.
Grand Canyon National Monument is created.
The University of the Philippines College of Law is formally established; three future Philippine presidents are among the first enrollees.
National convention of black leaders meets in Washington D.C.
Bruno Hauptmann goes on trial for the murder of Charles Lindbergh Jr. infant son of aviator Charles Lindbergh.
Charles II is crowned King of Scotland.
Martial law is declared in Honduras to stop a revolt by banana workers fired by the United Fruit Company.
Topsy an elephant is electrocuted by the owners of Luna Park Coney Island. Thomas Edison's movie company shoots the film Electrocuting an Elephant of the execution.
The German Workers' Party which would become the Nazi Party is founded.
President-elect of the United States Franklin Pierce and his family are involved in a train wreck near Andover Massachusetts. Pierce's 11-year-old son Benjamin is killed in the crash.
Crazy Horse and his warriors fight their last battle against the United States Cavalry at Wolf Mountain Montana Territory.
American Civil War: The "Star of the West" incident occurs near Charleston South Carolina. It is considered by some historians to be the "First Shots of the American Civil War".
The Treaty of Versailles takes effect officially ending World War I.
Immigrant textile works in Lawrence Massachusetts go on strike when wages are reduced in response to a mandated shortening of the work week.
The United States House of Representatives rejects a proposal to give women the right to vote.
The Independent Labour Party of the United Kingdom holds its first meeting.
World War II: German bombing severely damages the Llandaff Cathedral in Cardiff Wales United Kingdom.
Russia begins using the Anno Domini era and no longer uses the Anno Mundi era of the Byzantine Empire.
Minnie D. Craig becomes the first female elected as Speaker of the North Dakota House of Representatives the first female to hold a Speaker position anywhere in the United States.
The Scout Association is incorporated throughout the British Empire by royal charter.
Nellie Tayloe Ross of Wyoming becomes the first female governor in the United States.
The inauguration of the Musikverein in Vienna Austria.
Herman Hollerith is issued US patent #395791 for the 'Art of Applying Statistics' — his punched card calculator.
Mississippi becomes the second state to secede from the Union before the outbreak of the American Civil War.
Arthur Griffith is elected President of the Dáil Éireann.
The Kingsland munitions factory explosion occurs as a result of sabotage.
Finland's "Mosaic Confessors" law goes into effect making Finnish Jews full citizens.
U.S. Marines land in Honolulu Hawaii from the USS Boston to prevent the queen from abrogating the Bayonet Constitution.
The Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) convicts 33 members of a German spy ring headed by Fritz Joubert Duquesne in the largest espionage case in United States history—the Duquesne Spy Ring.
John V is crowned King of Portugal.
The March of Dimes is established by President Franklin D. Roosevelt.
World War II: Operation Carpetbagger involving the dropping of arms and supplies to resistance fighters in Europe begins.
Construction of the Golden Gate Bridge begins in San Francisco Bay.
The Washington National Cathedral is chartered by Congress. The charter is signed by President Benjamin Harrison.
The Blackstone Library is dedicated marking the beginning of the Chicago Public Library system.
American Civil War: the Battle of Fort Hindman begins in Arkansas.
Lithuania seizes and annexes Memel.
Romania reincorporates Transylvania.
Acting to restore confidence in baseball after the Black Sox Scandal Judge Kenesaw Mountain Landis is elected as Major League Baseball's first commissioner.
First Italo-Ethiopian War: the war's opening battle the Battle of Coatit occurs; it is an Italian victory.
World War II: Manila Philippines is captured by Japanese forces.
Bouvet Island is discovered by French explorer Jean-Baptiste Charles Bouvet de Lozier.
World War II: Top Ace Major Greg "Pappy" Boyington is shot down in his Vought F4U Corsair by Captain Masajiro Kawato flying a Mitsubishi A6M Zero.
Burma gains its independence from the United Kingdom.
The Daily Mail becomes the first transoceanic newspaper.
Second Boer War: Having already sieged the fortress at Ladysmith Boer forces attack it but are driven back by British defenders.
A landslide in Haverstraw New York caused by the excavation of clay along the Hudson River kills 20 people.
Umberto I becomes King of Italy.
Fritz Lang's futuristic film Metropolis is released in Germany.
First use of insulin to treat diabetes in a human patient.
Original Sam 'n' Henry aired on Chicago radio later renamed Amos 'n' Andy in 1928.
Émile Zola's J'accuse exposes the Dreyfus affair.
World War II: Nuremberg Germany (in German Nürnberg) is severely bombed by Allied forces.
The first traveler's cheques which can be used in 90 European cities go on sale in London England.
World War II: Admiral Chester W. Nimitz is placed in command of all U.S. Naval forces in preparation for planned assaults against Iwo Jima and Okinawa in Japan.
Korean War: Chinese and North Korean forces capture Seoul.
The Soviet Union recognizes the new pro-Soviet government of Poland.
Maria Montessori opens her first school and daycare center for working class children in Rome Italy.
The African National Congress is founded.
The Great Gale of 1880 devastates parts of Oregon and Washington with high winds and heavy snow.
The Adventures of Tintin one of the most popular European comic books is first published in Belgium.
Occupation of the Ruhr: Troops from France and Belgium occupy the Ruhr area to force Germany to make its World War I reparation payments.
Hattie Caraway becomes the first woman elected to the United States Senate.
The Rhoads Opera House Fire in Boyertown Pennsylvania kills 171 people.
Luis Muñoz Marín becomes the first democratically elected Governor of Puerto Rico.
The hymn that became known as "Amazing Grace" then titled "1 Chronicles 17:16
column2: 17" is first used to accompany a sermon led by John Newton in the town of Olney England.

column1: Popular Canadian American jockey George Woolf dies in a freak accident during a race; the annual George Woolf Memorial Jockey Award is created to honor him.
The Greek National Radical Union is formed by Konstantinos Karamanlis.
United States President Harry S. Truman unveils his Fair Deal program.
New Mexico is admitted to the Union as the 47th U.S. state.
President Woodrow Wilson announces his "Fourteen Points" for the aftermath of World War I.
New England Telephone and Telegraph installs the first battery-operated telephone switchboard in Lexington Massachusetts.
World War II: The Greek army captures Kleisoura.
Louis B. Mayer head of film studio Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer (MGM) announces the creation of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences at a banquet in Los Angeles California.
World War II: United States President Franklin D. Roosevelt creates the National War Labor Board.
The first public radio broadcast takes place; a live performance of the opera Cavalleria rusticana is sent out over the airwaves from the Metropolitan Opera House in New York New York.
Panamanian president José Antonio Remón Cantera is assassinated.
American Revolutionary War: Norfolk Virginia is burned by combined Royal Navy and Continental Army action.
Proceedings of the U.S. Congress are televised for the first time.
Sputnik 1 falls to Earth from orbit.
In a speech given to the United States Congress United States President Dwight D. Eisenhower announces the establishment of what will later be called the Eisenhower Doctrine.
German geophysicist Alfred Wegener first presents his theory of continental drift.
The steel strike of 1919 ends in a complete failure for the Amalgamated Association of Iron Steel and Tin Workers labor union.
Hallam Tennyson 2nd Baron Tennyson son of the poet Alfred Tennyson becomes the second Governor-General of Australia.
The first General Assembly of the United Nations opens in London. Fifty-one nations are represented.
Amelia Earhart becomes the first person to fly solo from Hawaii to California.
The Caves of Nerja are rediscovered in Spain.
Delta Sigma Theta Sorority Incorporated was founded on the campus of Howard University.
Luna 1 the first spacecraft to reach the vicinity of the Moon and to orbit the Sun is launched by the Soviet Union.

American Revolutionary War: One thousand five hundred soldiers of the 6th Pennsylvania Regiment under General Anthony Wayne's command rebel against the Continental Army's winter camp in Morristown New Jersey in the Pennsylvania Line Mutiny of 1781.
The Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas the central bank of the Philippines is established.
Luna 1 becomes the first spacecraft to reach the vicinity of the Moon.
Alexander Dubček comes to power: "Prague Spring" begins in Czechoslovakia.
Formation of the Iraqi Army.
World War II: Britain introduces food rationing.
Ernest Shackleton leading the Nimrod Expedition to the South Pole plants the British flag 97 nautical miles (180 km; 112 mi) from the South Pole the farthest anyone had ever reached at that time.
The United States Army Signal Corps successfully conducts Project Diana bouncing radio waves off the Moon and receiving the reflected signals.
World War II: The Japanese capture Kuala Lumpur.
Vietnam War: Operation Chopper the first American combat mission in the war takes place.
An earthquake in Avezzano Italy kills 29800.
Vietnam War: The Viet Cong wins its first major victory in the Battle of Ap Bac.
First edition of The Times of London previously The Daily Universal Register is published.
Frances P. Bolton and her son Oliver from Ohio become the first mother and son to serve simultaneously in the U.S. Congress.
United States President Lyndon B. Johnson proclaims his "Great Society" during his State of the Union address.
The Troubles: The Royal Ulster Constabulary raid the Bogside area of Derry damaging property and beating residents. In response residents erect barricades and establish Free Derry.
King Alexander of the Serbs Croats and Slovenes suspends his country's constitution (the January 6th Dictatorship).
World War II: Philippine Commonwealth troops under the Philippine Commonwealth Army units enter the province of Ilocos Sur in Northern Luzon and attack Japanese Imperial forces.
Phi Beta Sigma Fraternity Inc. the first historically black intercollegiate Greek-letter fraternity to be officially recognized at Howard University is founded.
BOAC Flight 781 a de Havilland DH.106 Comet 1 explodes and falls into the Tyrrhenian Sea killing 35 people.
World War II: The United States and United Kingdom give up territorial rights in China.
Rebels in Zanzibar begin a revolt known as the Zanzibar Revolution and proclaim a republic.
The Candidate of Sciences degree is established in the Soviet Union.
Ronald Reagan sworn in as Governor of California
The Dutch East India Company is dissolved.
A fire damages the top part of the Eiffel Tower.
A military coup takes place in Upper Volta (later Burkina Faso) dissolving the National Parliament and leading to a new national constitution.
United States President Richard Nixon orders the development of a Space Shuttle program.
Mother Teresa arrives in Calcutta India to begin her work among India's poorest and sick people.
Operation Auca: Five U.S. missionaries are killed by the Huaorani of Ecuador shortly after making contact with them.
World War I: The Battle of Gallipoli concludes with an Ottoman Empire victory when the last Allied forces are evacuated from the peninsula.
Apollo program: NASA announces plans to build the C-5 rocket launch vehicle. It became better known as the Saturn V Moon rocket which launched every Apollo Moon mission.
Italian-American anarchist Carlo Tresca is assassinated in New York City.
Lyndon B. Johnson states that the United States should stay in South Vietnam until Communist aggression there is ended.
A plebiscite in Saarland shows that 90.3% of those voting wish to join Nazi Germany.
The second Ibrox disaster kills 66 fans at a Rangers-Celtic association football (soccer) match.
The legislative union of Kingdom of Great Britain and Kingdom of Ireland is completed to form the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland.
The Hamilton Watch Company introduces the first electric watch.
A magnitude 7.7 earthquake strikes Tonghai County China killing at least 15000 people.
An earthquake in Lima Peru kills six people and damages hundreds of houses.
The first diesel-engined automobile trip is completed from Indianapolis Indiana to New York New York.
In France a referendum supports Charles de Gaulle's policies in Algeria.
World War I: the Battle of Rafa is fought near the Egyptian border with Palestine.
A by-poll is held in the Lebanese Chouf District.
Greek Civil War: Last day of the Dekemvriana clashes in Athens Greece.
Dr. James Bedford becomes the first person to be cryonically preserved with intent of future resuscitation.
The Black Friday bush fires burn 20000 square kilometers of land in Australia claiming the lives of 71 people.
United States President Richard Nixon signs a bill lowering the maximum U.S. speed limit to 55 MPH in order to conserve gasoline during an OPEC embargo.
The dwarf planet Ceres is discovered by Giuseppe Piazzi.
The West Indies Federation is formed.
Rose Heilbron becomes the first female judge to sit at the Old Bailey in London England.
Warmest reliably measured temperature in Antarctica of +59 °F (+15 °C) recorded at Vanda Station
Thomas Edison submits his last patent application.
The Harmelen train disaster killed 93 people in the Netherlands.
Battle of Bear Valley: The last battle of the American Indian Wars.
Sheikh Mujibur Rahman returns to the newly independent Bangladesh as president after spending over nine months in prison in Pakistan.
Enver Hoxha Secretary General of the Communist Party of Albania declares the People's Republic of Albania with himself as head of state.

The New York Jets of the American Football League defeat the Baltimore Colts of the National Football League to win Super Bowl III in what is considered to be one of the greatest upsets in sports history.
Henry Ford patents a plastic automobile which is 30% lighter than a regular car.
A bomb blast at Samastipur Bihar India fatally wounds Minister of Railways Lalit Narayan Mishra.
Emperor Gia Long orders all bronze wares of the Tây Sơn dynasty to be collected and melted into nine cannons for the Royal Citadel in Huế Vietnam.
Alaska is admitted as the 49th U.S. state.
United States President Richard Nixon refuses to hand over materials subpoenaed by the Senate Watergate Committee.
The Tasman Bridge in Tasmania Australia is struck by the bulk ore carrier Lake Illawarra killing twelve people.
United States President Franklin D. Roosevelt delivers his Four Freedoms speech in the State of the Union address.
Leonardo da Vinci's Mona Lisa is exhibited in the United States for the first time at the National Gallery of Art in Washington D.C.
Greco-Turkish War: The First Battle of İnönü the first battle of the war begins near Eskişehir in Anatolia.
Salvadoran Civil War: The FMLN launches its first major offensive gaining control of most of Morazán and Chalatenango departments
The first "networked" television broadcasts take place as KDKA-TV in Pittsburgh Pennsylvania goes on the air connecting the east coast and mid-west programming.
Biafra capitulates ending the Nigerian Civil War.
World War II: First use of an aircraft ejection seat by a German test pilot in a Heinkel He 280 jet fighter.
Bangladeshi Marxist leader Siraj Sikder is arrested and dies while in police custody.
French rule ends in Haiti. Haiti becomes the first black republic and second independent country in North America after the United States
Separatists in the Maldives declare the establishment of the United Suvadive Republic.
The Troubles: The Ulster Volunteer Force shoots dead six Irish Catholic civilians in County Armagh Northern Ireland. The next day gunmen shoot dead ten Protestant civilians nearby in retaliation.
The Khmer Rouge proclaim the Constitution of Democratic Kampuchea.
The first general election ever in Vietnam is held.
President Lyndon B. Johnson declares a "War on Poverty" in the United States.
Juan de la Cierva makes the first autogyro flight.
Holy See
column2: United States relations: The United States and Holy See (Vatican City) re-establish full diplomatic relations after almost 117 years overturning the United States Congress's 1867 ban on public funding for such a diplomatic envoy.

column1: A record-setting snowstorm hits Los Angeles California.

The Harrisburg Seven: Reverend Philip Berrigan and five others are indicted on charges of conspiring to kidnap Henry Kissinger and of plotting to blow up the heating tunnels of federal buildings in Washington D.C.
First Indochina War: The Battle of Vĩnh Yên begins which will end in a major victory for France.
The Gale of January 1976 begins which results in coastal flooding around the southern North Sea coasts resulting in at least 82 deaths and US$1.3 billion in damage.
The French Republican Calendar is abolished.
The United States severs diplomatic relations with Cuba over the latter's nationalization of American assets.
The 1987 Maryland train collision: An Amtrak train en route to Boston from Washington D.C. collides with Conrail engines in Chase Maryland killing 16 people.
The Troubles: In response to the killing of six Catholics the night before gunmen shoot dead ten Protestant civilians after stopping their minibus at Kingsmill in County Armagh Northern Ireland UK.
Pan American Airlines becomes the first commercial airline to schedule a flight around the world.

Bowing to international pressure President of Pakistan Zulfikar Ali Bhutto releases Bengali leader Sheikh Mujibur Rahman from prison who had been arrested after declaring the independence of Bangladesh.
Lithuanian residents of the Memel Territory rebel against the League of Nations' decision to leave the area as a mandated region under French control.
Sir Clive Sinclair launches the Sinclair C5 personal electric vehicle which became a notorious commercial failure and later a cult collector's item.
The African Convention is founded in Dakar Senegal.
All in the Family The famous situation comedy premieres on CBS

An article appears in Pravda accusing some of the most prestigious and prominent doctors mostly Jews in the Soviet Union of taking part in a vast plot to poison members of the top Soviet political and military leadership.
One of the largest investigations by a British police force ends when serial killer Peter Sutcliffe the "Yorkshire Ripper" is arrested in Sheffield South Yorkshire.
The importation of slaves into the United States is banned.
A core explosion and meltdown at the SL-1 a government-run reactor near Idaho Falls Idaho kills three workers.
Second Gulf of Sidra incident: a pair of Libyan MiG-23 "Floggers" are shot down by a pair of US Navy F-14 Tomcats during an air-to-air confrontation.
Georgian forces enter Tskhinvali the capital of South Ossetia Georgia opening the 1991
The United Kingdom recognizes the People's Republic of China. The Republic of China severs diplomatic relations with the UK in response.
Soviet space mission Luna 21 is launched.
A fire at the Laurier Palace movie theatre in Montreal Quebec Canada kills 78 children.

Sandinista Daniel Ortega becomes president of Nicaragua and vows to continue the transformation to socialism and alliance with the Soviet Union and Cuba; American policy continues to support the Contras in their revolt against the Nicaraguan government.
Henry Lee Lucas once listed as America's most prolific serial killer commits his first known murder.
The United Nations Security Council votes 11-1 to allow the Palestine Liberation Organization to participate in a Security Council debate (without voting rights).
The Moroccan Army of Liberation ambushes a Spanish patrol in the Battle of Edchera.
Leaders of armed opposition declare the President Zviad Gamsakhurdia deposed during a military coup in Georgia.
Major-General Lachlan Macquarie officially becomes Governor of New South Wales
In Finland's worst civilian aviation accident an Aero Flight 311 crashes near Kvevlax resulting in the deaths of all 25 people aboard.
In Pakistan's deadliest train accident an overloaded passenger train collides with an empty freight train resulting in 307 deaths and 700 injuries.
The United States Embassy to Somalia in Mogadishu is evacuated by helicopter airlift days after violence enveloped Mogadishu during the Somali Civil War
Korean War: An estimated 200
column2: 1300 South Korean communist sympathizers are slaughtered in what becomes the Ganghwa massacre.

column1: Watergate scandal: The trial of seven men accused of illegal entry into Democratic Party headquarters at Watergate begins.
Paul of Greece marries Frederica of Hanover in Athens.
Time Warner is formed by the merger of Time Inc. and Warner Communications.
Cold War: While tied to its pier in Polyarny the Soviet submarine B-37 is destroyed when fire breaks out in its torpedo compartment.
Space Shuttle program: Congressman Bill Nelson lifts off from Kennedy Space Center aboard Columbia on mission STS-61-C as a Mission Specialist.
The Gulag system of forced labor camps in the Soviet Union is officially abolished.
Sri Lankan Civil War: The Sri Lanka Navy kill 35-100 civilians on the Jaffna Lagoon.
The Bishop of Durham Shute Barrington orders troops from Durham Castle to break up a miners' strike in Chester-le-Street Co. Durham
Pope John XXIII excommunicates Fidel Castro.
Wilaya of Relizane massacres in Algeria: over 170 are killed in three remote villages.
The oil tanker MV Braer runs aground on the coast of the Shetland Islands spilling 84700 tons of crude oil.
The first Asian Socialist Conference opens in Rangoon Burma.
Ella T. Grasso becomes Governor of Connecticut the first woman to serve as a Governor in the United States other than by succeeding her husband.
World War II: First flight of the Avro Lancaster.
Sanjeev Nanda kills three policemen in New Delhi India with his car an act for which he was later acquitted resulting in a sharp drop in public confidence in the Indian legal system.
An avalanche on Huascarán in Peru causes 4000 deaths.
Gulf War: An act of the U.S. Congress authorizes the use of military force to drive Iraq out of Kuwait.
Coup d'état in Togo results in assassination of president Sylvanus Olympio

A brutal snowstorm smashes into the Midwestern United States causing 14 inches (359 mm) of snow in Milwaukee Wisconsin and 19 inches (487 mm) in Chicago where temperatures plunge to -13 °F (-25 °C); 68 deaths are reported.
The Greek Constitution of 1822 is adopted by the First National Assembly at Epidaurus.
The International Covenant on Economic Social and Cultural Rights comes into effect.
A massive ice storm hits eastern Canada and the northeastern United States continuing through January 10 and causing widespread destruction.

Eris the largest known dwarf planet in the Solar System is discovered by the team of Michael E. Brown Chad Trujillo and David L. Rabinowitz using images originally taken on October 21 2003 at the Palomar Observatory.
National Airlines Flight 2511 is destroyed in mid-air by a bomb while en route from New York City to Miami.
Three bombs explode in Moscow Russia Soviet Union within 37 minutes killing seven. The bombings are attributed to an Armenian separatist group.
World War II: The United States invades Luzon in the Philippines.
A mudslide occurs in La Conchita California killing 10 people injuring many more and closing U.S. Route 101 the main coastal corridor between Los Angeles and San Francisco for 10 days.

Surgeon General of the United States Dr. Luther Terry M.D. publishes the landmark report Smoking and Health: Report of the Advisory Committee to the Surgeon General of the United States saying that smoking may be hazardous to health sparking national and worldwide anti-smoking efforts.
Nineteen European nations agree to forbid human cloning.
Anti-Muslim riots break out in Calcutta resulting in 100 deaths.
Stardust successfully flies past Comet Wild 2 collecting samples that are returned to Earth.
The United Kingdom claims sovereignty over the Falkland Islands.
Apple Computer is incorporated.
Former professional wrestler Jesse Ventura is sworn in as governor of Minnesota.
A launch of the communication satellite GSAT-14 aboard the GSLV MK.II D5 marks the first successful flight of an Indian cryogenic engine.
The Associations Law comes into force in Iraq allowing registration of political parties.
The tanker Betelgeuse explodes in Bantry Bay Ireland.
Elizabeth "Betty" Short the Black Dahlia is last seen alive.
A general strike begins in Guinea in an eventually successful attempt to get President Lansana Conté to resign.
East Pakistan renames itself Bangladesh.
Downtown Disney opens to the public as part of the Disneyland Resort in Anaheim California.
Karol Wojtyla the future Pope John Paul II is appointed archbishop of Kraków Poland.
An explosion in a coal mine in Sago West Virginia traps and kills 12 miners while leaving one miner in critical condition.
The Cobble Hill Tunnel in Brooklyn New York City is completed.
Former leader of Panama Manuel Noriega surrenders to American forces.
Two trains on the Røros Line collide in Åsta Norway resulting in an explosive fire and 19 deaths.
Vietnam War: United States Marine Corps and ARVN troops launch "Operation Deckhouse Five" in the Mekong River delta.
A local farmer reports a UFO sighting in Trans-en-Provence France claimed to be "perhaps the most completely and carefully documented sighting of all time".
British Prime Minister Sir Anthony Eden resigns from office following his failure to retake the Suez Canal from Egyptian sovereignty.

column2: 11 Queensland floods: Torrential rain in the Lockyer Valley region of South East Queensland Australia causes severe flash flooding killing 9 people.

column1: Major League Baseball owners vote in approval of the American League adopting the designated hitter position.
The world's largest ocean liner RMS Queen Mary 2 makes its maiden voyage.
Robert C. Weaver becomes the first African American Cabinet member when he is appointed United States Secretary of Housing and Urban Development.
January 2011 Baghdad shootings take place.
The world's first "Mercy" Hospital is founded in Pittsburgh by the Sisters of Mercy the name will go on to grace over 30 major hospitals throughout the world.
In Moscow Russia George Bush and Boris Yeltsin sign the second Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty (START).
Spirit a NASA Mars rover lands successfully on Mars at 04:35 UTC.
In response to the 1973 oil crisis daylight saving time commences nearly four months early in the United States.
Breakup of the Bell System: AT&T agrees to divest itself of twenty-two subdivisions.
President of Egypt Gamal Abdel Nasser opens construction on the Aswan Dam by detonating ten tons of dynamite to demolish twenty tons of granite on the east bank of the Nile.
A bombing in Khyber Agency Pakistan kills at least 30 people and 78 others injured.
The Gateway Bridge Brisbane in Queensland Australia is officially opened.
Deep Impact launches from Cape Canaveral on a Delta II rocket.
Johnny Cash performs live at Folsom State Prison
Barack Obama signs the American Taxpayer Relief Act of 2012.
First Polish stamp is issued.
More than seven million people from the former apartheid Homelands receive South African citizenship.
Mikheil Saakashvili is elected President of Georgia following the November 2003 Rose Revolution.
The Crown of St. Stephen (also known as the Holy Crown of Hungary) is returned to Hungary from the United States where it was held after World War II.
Kegworth air disaster: British Midland Flight 92 a Boeing 737-400 crashes into the M1 motorway killing 47 of the 126 people on board.
Martyrs' Day: Several Panamanian youths try to raise the Panamanian flag on the U.S.-controlled Panama Canal Zone leading to fighting between U.S. military and Panamanian civilians.
More than 100 people are killed and 270 injured in several bomb blasts in Pakistan.
The Irish Government announces the end of a 15-year broadcasting ban on the IRA and its political arm Sinn Féin.
A stampede during the Stoning of the Devil ritual on the last day at the Hajj in Mina Saudi Arabia kills at least 362 Muslim pilgrims.
Prime Minister Kofi Abrefa Busia and President Edward Akufo-Addo of Ghana are ousted in a bloodless military coup by Colonel Ignatius Kutu Acheampong.
Porfirio Díaz conquers Mexico City Mexico.
The Motorola StarTAC the first flip phone and one of the first mobile phones to gain widespread consumer adoption goes on sale.
Prime Minister Ariel Sharon of Israel suffers a second apparently more serious stroke. His authority is transferred to acting Prime Minister Ehud Olmert.
President of Georgia Zviad Gamsakhurdia flees the country as a result of the military coup.
Beginning of Japanese Heisei period.
The Mirzapur Cadet College formally opens for academic activities in East Pakistan (now Bangladesh).
A mass poisoning at a funeral in Mozambique involves beer that was deliberately contaminated with crocodile bile leaving at least 56 dead and nearly 200 hospitalized.
Space Shuttle program: STS-72 launches from the Kennedy Space Center marking the start of the 74th Space Shuttle mission and the 10th flight of Endeavour.
The French warship Clemenceau reaches Egypt and is barred access to the Suez Canal. Greenpeace activists board the ship.
Seraphim is elected Archbishop of Athens and All Greece.
American Civil War: The Emancipation Proclamation takes effect in Confederate territory.
China announces it will spend US$27.7 billion to fight erosion and pollution in the Yangtze and Yellow River valleys.
The 110th United States Congress convenes electing Nancy Pelosi as the first female Speaker of the House in U.S. history.
Indian Border Security Force units kill 55 Kashmiri civilians in Sopore Jammu and Kashmir in revenge after militants ambushed a BSF patrol.
Russian cosmonaut Valeri Polyakov on Soyuz TM-18 leaves for Mir. He would stay on the space station until March 22 1995 for a record 437 days in space.
Representatives from the United States and Iraq meet at the Geneva Peace Conference to try to find a peaceful resolution to the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait.

A traffic accident between an oil tanker truck and passenger coach en route to Shikarpur from Karachi on the Pakistan National Highway Link Road near Gulshan-e-Hadeed Karachi kills at least 62 people.
Over 100 people are killed in the Sidi-Hamed massacre in Algeria.
Comet C/2006 P1 (McNaught) reaches perihelion becoming the brightest comet in more than 40 years.
United States Food and Drug Administration requires all blood donations to be labeled "paid" or "volunteer" donors.
The first claim under the Homestead Act is made by Daniel Freeman for a farm in Nebraska.
The Mars Polar Lander is launched.
Burj Khalifa the world's tallest building is officially opened.
Nancy Kerrigan is clubbed on the knee at the U.S. Figure Skating Championships in Detroit.
An Antonov An-32 cargo aircraft crashes into a crowded market in Kinshasa Zaire killing up to 237 on the ground; the aircraft's crew of six survive the crash.
The Assembly of the Serb People in Bosnia and Herzegovina proclaims the creation of Republika Srpska a new state within Yugoslavia.
Illinois Governor George Ryan commutes the death sentences of 167 prisoners on Illinois' death row based on the Jon Burge scandal.
An earthquake occurs killing an estimated 316000 and destroying the majority of the capital Port-au-Prince.
Shortly after takeoff Air Florida Flight 90 a Boeing 737 jet crashes into Washington D.C.'s 14th Street Bridge and falls into the Potomac River killing 78 including four motorists.
Adolf Loos architect co-founder of modern architecture baptized in St. Thomas church Brno Moravia
Israel detains and later expels 14 members of Concerned Christians.
A gunman kills eight people in a house-to-house rampage in Kawit the Philippines.
A chemical fire in an apartment complex in Manila Philippines leads to the discovery of plans for Project Bojinka a mass-terrorist attack.
President George W. Bush signs into law the No Child Left Behind Act.

First Chechen War: Chechen separatists launch a raid against the helicopter airfield and later a civilian hospital in the city of Kizlyar in the neighboring Dagestan which turns into a massive hostage crisis involving thousands of civilians.
One French soldier and 17 militants are killed in a failed attempt to free a French hostage in Bulo Marer Somalia.

Violent protests occur in Bucharest Romania as two-day-old demonstrations continue against President Traian Băsescu's economic austerity measures. Clashes are reported in numerous Romanian cities between protesters and law enforcement officers.
A passenger train plunges into a ravine in Ethiopia killing 428 in the worst railroad disaster in Africa.
Japan begins using the Gregorian calendar.
The last original weekday Peanuts comic strip is published.
Celia the last Pyrenean ibex was found dead after a tree had landed on her.
Turkish Airlines Flight 634 crashes near Diyarbakır Airport Turkey killing the entire crew and 70 of 75 passengers.
An inflatable boat carrying illegal Albanian emigrants stalls near the Karaburun Peninsula while on the way to Brindisi Italy; exposure to the elements kills 28.
Cameroon kills 143 Boko Haram fighters in clashes.
A month-long violent struggle begins in Aden South Yemen between supporters of Ali Nasir Muhammad and Abdul Fattah Ismail resulting in thousands of casualties.
Queen Victoria of the United Kingdom is proclaimed Empress of India.
Israeli forces seize the Palestinian freighter Karine A in the Red Sea finding 50 tons of weapons.
American Civil Rights Movement: Edgar Ray Killen is arrested as a suspect in the 1964 murders of three civil rights workers.
Air Midwest Flight 5481 crashes at Charlotte-Douglas Airport Charlotte North Carolina killing all 21 people on board.
Mahmoud Abbas wins the election to replace Yasser Arafat as President of the Palestinian National Authority. He replaces interim president Rawhi Fattouh.
A serviceman stationed at the Russian 102nd Military Base kills seven people in Gyumri Armenia.
Lee Teng-hui becomes the first native Taiwanese President of the Republic of China.
Ferdinand de Lesseps begins French construction of the Panama Canal.
Flash Airlines Flight 604 crashes into the Red Sea resulting in 148 deaths making it the deadliest aviation accident in Egyptian history.
A train collision in Graniteville South Carolina releases about 60 tons of chlorine gas.
The RMS Queen Mary 2 the largest passenger ship ever built is christened by her namesake's granddaughter Queen Elizabeth II.
The Sudan People's Liberation Movement and the Government of Sudan sign the Comprehensive Peace Agreement to end the Second Sudanese Civil War.
a seven-day pogrom breaks out against the Armenian civilian population of Baku Azerbaijan during which Armenians were beaten tortured murdered and expelled from the city.
Twenty-five nations adopt Sandford Fleming's proposal for standard time (and also time zones)
The first block of the blockchain of the decentralized payment system Bitcoin called the Genesis block was established by the creator of the system Satoshi Nakamoto.
Israel conducts an assault on the Gaza Strip
The nuclear sub USS San Francisco collides at full speed with an undersea mountain south of Guam. One man is killed but the sub surfaces and is repaired.
Apple CEO Steve Jobs unveils the first iPhone.
Douglas Wilder becomes the first elected African American governor as he takes office in Richmond Virginia.
Eritrea is consolidated into a colony by the Italian government.
Boko Haram militants raze the entire town of Baga in north-east Nigeria with as many as 2000 people having been killed.
26 people are killed and 63 wounded when a suicide bomber blows himself up at a police station in Damascus.
A 6.1-magnitude earthquake in northern Costa Rica kills 15 people and injures 32.
Iran Air Flight 277 crashes near Orumiyeh in the northeast of the country killing 77 people.
Soviet Union troops attack Lithuanian independence supporters in Vilnius killing 14 people and wounding 1000.
The Rose Parade in Pasadena California is first held.
Gunmen from an offshoot the Front for the Liberation of the Enclave of Cabinda attacked the bus carrying the Togo national football team on its way to the 2010 Africa Cup of Nations killing three.
A SeaStreak ferry traveling to lower Manhattan New York City crashes into the dock injuring 85 people.
Space Shuttle program: Endeavour heads for space for the third time as STS-54 launches from the Kennedy Space Center.
Ellis Island opens to begin processing immigrants into the United States.

The attempted assassination of Arizona Representative Gabrielle Giffords and subsequent shooting in Casas Adobes Arizona at a Safeway grocery store for which Jared Lee Loughner is subsequently arrested kills six people and wounds 13 including Giffords.
An explosion at a Mitsubishi Materials chemical plant in Yokkaichi Japan kills at least five people and injures 17 others.
An earthquake hits El Salvador killing more than 800.
The Manchester Ship Canal is officially opened to traffic.

The perpetrators of the Charlie Hebdo shooting in Paris two days earlier are both killed after a hostage situation. Elsewhere a second hostage situation related to the Charlie Hebdo shooting occurs at a Jewish market Hypercacher in the eastern Paris suburb of Vincennes.
The passenger cruise ship Costa Concordia sinks off the coast of Italy. There are 32 confirmed deaths amongst the 4232 passengers and crew.

New York New York annexes land from surrounding counties creating the City of Greater New York. The four initial boroughs Manhattan Brooklyn Queens and The Bronx are joined on January 25 by Staten Island to create the modern city of five boroughs.
The opening ceremony of the Winter Youth Olympics takes place in Innsbruck Austria.
Spanish rule ends in Cuba.
Nigeria becomes a British protectorate.

The British colonies of New South Wales Queensland Victoria South Australia Tasmania and Western Australia federate as the Commonwealth of Australia; Edmund Barton is appointed the first Prime Minister.
The first American college football bowl game the Rose Bowl between Michigan and Stanford is held in Pasadena California.
British India officially adopts Indian Standard Time.
For the first time a ball is dropped in New York City's Times Square to signify the start of the New Year at midnight.
Drilling begins on the Lakeview Gusher.
Captain David Beatty is promoted to Rear admiral and becomes the youngest admiral in the Royal Navy (except for Royal family members) since Horatio Nelson.
Northern Territory is separated from South Australia and transferred to Commonwealth control.
The Republic of China is established.
The British Board of Censors is established.
German troops abandon Yaoundé and their Kamerun colony to British forces and begin the long march to Spanish Guinea.
The Belorussian Communist Organisation is founded as a separate party.
Britain's Railways are grouped into the Big Four: LNER GWR SR and LMS.
The Cristero War begins in Mexico.
Turkey adopts the Gregorian calendar: December 18 1926 (Julian) is immediately followed by January 1 1927 (Gregorian).
Boris Bazhanov defects through Iran. He is the only assistant of Joseph Stalin's secretariat to have defected from the Eastern Bloc.
The former municipalities of Point Grey British Columbia and South Vancouver British Columbia are amalgamated into Vancouver.
The United States Post Office Department issues a set of 12 stamps commemorating the 200th anniversary of George Washington's birth.
Alcatraz Island becomes a United States federal prison.
Nazi Germany passes the "Law for the Prevention of Genetically Diseased Offspring".
Safety glass in vehicle windscreens becomes mandatory in the United Kingdom.
Sydney Australia swelters in 45 ˚C (113 ˚F) heat a record for the city.
The Declaration by United Nations is signed by twenty-six nations.
World War II: In retaliation for the Malmedy massacre U.S. troops massacre 30 SS prisoners at Chenogne.
World War II: The German Luftwaffe launches Operation Bodenplatte a massive but failed attempt to knock out Allied air power in northern Europe in a single blow.
The American and British occupation zones in Germany after World War II merge to form the Bizone which later (with the French zone) became part of West Germany.
The Canadian Citizenship Act 1946 comes into effect converting British subjects into Canadian citizens. Prime Minister William Lyon Mackenzie King becomes the first Canadian citizen.
The British railway network is nationalized to form British Railways.
The Constitution of Italy comes into force.
United Nations cease-fire takes effect in Kashmir from one minute before midnight. War between India and Pakistan stops accordingly.
Standard practice uses this day as the origin of the age scale Before Present
NBC makes the first coast-to-coast NTSC color broadcast when it telecast the Tournament of Roses Parade with public demonstrations given across the United States on prototype color receivers.
Sudan achieves independence from Egypt and the United Kingdom.
A new year event causes panic and stampedes at Yahiko Shrine Yahiko Niigata Japan killing at least 124 people.
George Town Penang becomes a city by a royal charter granted by Elizabeth II.
An Irish Republican Army (IRA) unit attacks Brookeborough RUC barracks during Operation Harvest; two IRA volunteers killed.
The European Economic Community is established.
Fulgencio Batista dictator of Cuba is overthrown by Fidel Castro's forces during the Cuban Revolution.
Cameroon achieves independence from France and the United Kingdom.
Western Samoa achieves independence from New Zealand; its name is changed to the Independent State of Western Samoa.
United States Navy SEALs established.
The Federation of Rhodesia and Nyasaland is divided into the independent republics of Zambia and Malawi and the British-controlled Rhodesia.
The People's Democratic Party of Afghanistan is founded in Kabul Afghanistan.
A twelve-day New York City transit strike begins.
After a coup Colonel Jean-Bédel Bokassa assumes power as president of the Central African Republic.
Unix time begins at 00:00:00 UTC/GMT.
Cigarette advertisements are banned on American television.
Hellenic Railways Organisation the Greek national railway company is founded.
Denmark the United Kingdom and Ireland are admitted into the European Economic Community.
Charter 77 published its first document.
Air India Flight 855 Boeing 747 crashes into the sea due to instrument failure and pilot disorientation off the coast of Bombay India killing 213.
The Constitution of the Northern Mariana Islands becomes effective.
Formal diplomatic relations are established between China and the United States.
Victoria is crowned princess of Sweden.
Greece is admitted into the European Community.
Palau achieves self-government though it is not independent from the United States.
Peruvian Javier Pérez de Cuéllar becomes the first Latin American to hold the title of Secretary-General of the United Nations.
ITV franchise ATV gets replaced by Central
The ARPANET officially changes to using the Internet Protocol creating the Internet.

The original American Telephone & Telegraph Company is divested of its 22 Bell System companies as a result of the settlement of the 1974 United States Department of Justice antitrust suit against AT&T.
Brunei becomes independent of the United Kingdom.
The first British mobile phone call is made by Michael Harrison to his father Sir Ernest Harrison chairman of Vodafone.
Aruba becomes independent of Curaçao though it remains in free association with the Netherlands.
Spain and Portugal are admitted into the European Community.
A value-added tax is introduced in Greece for the first time.
The Evangelical Lutheran Church in America comes into existence creating the largest Lutheran denomination in the United States.
The Montreal Protocol comes into force stopping the use of chemicals contributing to ozone depletion.
David Dinkins is sworn in as New York City's first black mayor.
The Russian Federation is formally established.
Dissolution of Czechoslovakia: Czechoslovakia is divided into Slovakia and the Czech Republic.
A single market within the European Community is introduced.
The Zapatista Army of National Liberation initiates twelve days of armed conflict in the Mexican state of Chiapas.
The North American Free Trade Agreement comes into effect.
The World Trade Organization goes into effect.
Sweden Austria and Finland are admitted into the European Union.
The Conference for Security and Co-operation in Europe becomes the Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe.
The Draupner wave in the North Sea in Norway is detected confirming the existence of freak waves.
Curaçao gains limited self-government though it remains within free association with the Netherlands.
Zaire officially joins the World Trade Organization.
Ghanaian diplomat Kofi Annan is appointed Secretary-General of the United Nations.
Russia begins to circulate new rubles to stem inflation and promote confidence.
The European Central Bank is established.
The Euro currency is introduced in 11 countries - members of the European Union (with the exception of the United Kingdom Denmark Greece and Sweden).
Euro banknotes and coins become legal tender in twelve of the European Union's member states.
Taiwan officially joins the World Trade Organization as Chinese Taipei.
The Open Skies mutual surveillance treaty initially signed in 1992 officially comes into force.

In a vote of confidence General Pervez Musharraf wins 658 out of 1170 votes in the Electoral College of Pakistan and according to Article 41(8) of the Constitution of Pakistan is "deemed to be elected" to the office of President until October 2007.
Bulgaria and Romania officially join the European Union. Slovenia joins Eurozone.
Adam Air Flight 574 disappears over Indonesia with 102 people on board.
Cyprus and Malta join the Eurozone.
Sixty-six people die in a nightclub fire in Bangkok Thailand.
Slovakia joins the Eurozone.
A suicide car bomber detonates at a volleyball tournament in Lakki Marwat Pakistan killing 105 and injuring 100 more.
A bomb explodes as Coptic Christians in Alexandria Egypt leave a new year service killing 23 people.
The Kallikratis plan becomes the new administrative system of Greece.
Estonia becomes the 17th member of the Eurozone.
A Moldovan civilian is fatally wounded by a Russian peacekeeper in the Transnistrian security zone leading to demonstrations against Russia.
At least 60 people are killed and 200 injured in a stampede after celebrations at Félix Houphouët-Boigny Stadium in Abidjan Ivory Coast.
Latvia becomes the 18th member of the Eurozone.
The Eurasian Economic Union comes into effect creating a political and economic union between Russia Belarus Armenia Kazakhstan and Kyrgyzstan.
Lithuania becomes the 19th member of the Eurozone.
